awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Chronic Kidney Disease, Environmental Risk and the Transformation of Agrarian Landscapes and Livelihoods
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how environmental illnesses reconfigure the relationships between health, knowledge, and agricultural modernization. In recent years a mysterious and severe form of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKDu) has emerged in several agricultural communities around the world. Those affected are predominantly young and middle aged male agricultural workers who do not suffer from the risk factors typically associated with kidney disease. While the exact cause of CKDu is still a source of scientific uncertainty, narratives that link the disease to the agrarian landscape have captivated popular imagination and influence farmers' cultivation practices, albeit in uneven, haphazard, and poorly understood ways. This project builds upon political ecology of health and science and technology studies (STS) to investigate how uncertainty about the cause of CKDu shapes health-environment interactions and agrarian landscapes and livelihoods. In doing so, it will account for the complex ways that farmers perceive and act on agricultural health risks while illuminating how contested understandings of environmental illnesses can fundamentally restructure agricultural practices, systems of production, and relations of expertise. Through this analysis, the proposed research will contribute directly to the development of policies and programs that facilitate agrarian livelihoods in the context of disease. 

Since the first reports of the emergence of a new form of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKDu) in the early 1990s, Sri Lanka's once peripheral dry zone has become the epicenter of an epidemic that is slowly crippling agricultural communities across the island's rice belt. The proposed project focuses on three dimensions of the relationship between CKDu and agricultural practices to explain how this scientifically contested illness is remade into an agricultural problem, and with what effects. First, the project investigates how ideas about the environment and its links to disease are formed, reinforced, and circulated. Second, it evaluates how farmers' cultivation practices are changing in response to the problem of CKDu and documents their shifts to native rice varieties and also to organic - or chemical free - systems of production, albeit in spatially uneven and sometimes transitory ways. Additionally, this study investigates how uncertainty about CKDu's cause mediates farmers' interactions with the environment and shapes the uneven adoption of native seeds as disease management strategies. Finally, the project examines how relationships between health and agricultural modernization in the dry zone have changed over time and inform contemporary agrarian shifts in response to CKDu. The project integrates archival research, ethnographic methods, and household surveys to study two dry zone farming communities. Findings of this research will provide insights into how contested agri-environmental-health problems shape practices of disease management and give rise to new forms of agricultural production. While this research is anchored in an analysis of shifting agrarian livelihoods in CKDu endemic areas of Sri Lanka, its findings will be applicable to other geographic regions where parallel epidemics of mystery kidney disease are found in agricultural communities such as India, Egypt, and Central America.

por.por_cntn:
This doctoral dissertation project examined everyday encounters with a severe and mysterious form of chronic kidney disease (CKDu) in Sri Lanka's dry zone. Supported by the National Science Foundation, the project involved 15 months of fieldwork in two kidney disease hotspots: the divisional secretariat divisions of Padaviya and Sri Pura. Through this fieldwork, I investigated residents' search for health in landscapes of disease, disease-related intervention, and intense and ongoing speculation about environmental risk. Empirically, I tacked back and forth among stories about disease (CKDu); about toxic uncertainty (how science explains or fails to explain the disease); and about health improvement schemes (how state and civil society actors attempt to manage CKDu). 

The NSF DDRI grant provided resources to conduct qualitative research from August 2017 to July 2018. The co-PI carried out fieldwork across a range of sites from libraries, farmers' fields, community events, and government offices. With support from the NSF, I conducted 150 in-depth interviews with residents, scientists, doctors, and civil society organization, 11 focus group discussions with dry zone residents, a structured survey of 222 households in my primary field sites, and  participant observation of farmers' fields and residents' food preparation and water procurement practices. This data allowed me to understand how speculation about health risks generates new consumption and cultivation practices in areas where mystery kidney disease is endemic. Through it, I also tracked the mechanisms driving these changes; the emergence of new sets of relations between residents and the environment; and the perspectives of people about the disease, environmental risk, as well as disease-mitigation responses in the region. 

Based on this in-depth research, the project revealed often hidden operations of power that shape health possibilities and create new fault lines of inequality in areas where CKDu is endemic. Specifically, I demonstrated that health interventions in both the water supply and agricultural sectors have worked to socially and spatially concentrate economic value, environmental advantage and potential health dividends among resource rich households and/or high-class urban consumers. More crucially, I illustrated how schemes designed to heal actually turn on the production of differentiatedharms, including intensified labour burdens for economically disadvantaged women and intensified agrochemical use for ecologically and economically resource poor farmers. I argue that the new harms that emerge from these health improvement strategies help explain why they are experienced in contradictory ways and produce effects that undermine their stated objectives. 

In addition, this research emphasized how the limited local uptake of 'healthful' consumption and cultivation practices in CKDu hotspots is tied to the narrow way that health improvement schemes spatialize risk, usually in backyard wells or in agrochemical inputs. In contrast, I argued that residents embody polyvalent health-environment relationships, balance different temporalities of risk, and often grapple with complex disease bundles which profoundly their shape practices and patterns of natural resource use. Specifically, I demonstrated that many residents reconcile chemically-dependent cultivation practices with heightened anxieties about chemical risk through considerations of short-term social reproduction, debt obligations, and taste preferences. Paradoxically, the testimonies of residents in CKDu hotspots illustrate that health improvement schemes intensify local dependence on agrochemicals, generate hybrid practices of resource use, and erode pre-existing forms of social reproduction.

More broadly, by integrating feminist work on intersectionality, visceral knowledge, and social reproduction into existing political ecologies of health literature, this research grapples with the polyvalence of health-environment relationships.  In doing so, this study contributes to geographic scholarship on the questions of health itself, what it means, who it is for and who decides. It demonstrates that greater engagement with feminist geography can draw attention to the instability of distinctions between what harms and what heals as well as the liminal or 'in between' states of health that people experience in everyday life. 

Finally, results were disseminated through publications and presentations in academic and public forums (both within and outside Sri Lanka). The project has also generated important knowledge that informs current policy debates in Sri Lanka about: markets for organic and traditional rice varieties, the challenges of shifting to agro-ecological practices, distortions in paddy markets, and local disease management strategies in Sri Lanka. Additionally, findings from this project have been shared inundergraduate courses on health-environment geography, political ecology, and sustainable development.
